reviewText: Soon after sound revolutionized the film industry, all the major studios exploited the novelty by producing elaborate musical extravaganzas that featured popular stage, screen, and radio stars of the day. Warner Brothers' obligatory entry was THE SHOW OF SHOWS, released in 1929 and directed by John G. Adolfi. Although it's not the best of Hollywood's early sound revues - that distinction belongs to Universal's THE KING OF JAZZ (1930) - this one has a lot of things in its favor that makes it worth checking out.Basically a statically filmed stage production, THE SHOW OF SHOWS has emcee Frank Fay stepping out in front of the curtain between acts engaging us with dry humor and innuendo. Over 70 stars go through their routines which range from John Barrymore's dramatic soliloquy from Shakespeare's "Henry VI", to Winnie Lightner's fun rendition of "Singing in the Bathtub", to Myrna Loy's exotic two-strip Technicolor dance sequence, "Li Po Li". Most of the numbers feature regimented, pre-Busby Berkeley chorus ensembles that were quite fashionable at the time. The grande finale - "Lady Luck" - elicits a charming naivete when a troupe of chubby, pom pom-capped chorines enters to perform some crude choreography involving cartwheels, splits, kicking backwards tapping head to toe, and hopping around on one leg while holding the other aloft. Punctuating the unintentional humor is the quaint musical phrasing during this clumsy display. It appears like there was another Technicolor segment halfway through "Lady Luck" that's apparently lost, as evidenced by a brief fade-out/fade-in at the reel change.Warner Archive's DVD-R of THE SHOW OF SHOWS is from a decent, though a bit soft source print and the soundtrack is clear.An interesting, entertaining antique from a bygone era, THE SHOW OF SHOWS will appeal to anyone who's into film history and the pop-culture of America's past.Recommended.
summary: GOOD ALL STAR EARLY TALKIE REVUE

reviewText: Full disclosure: I've loved the music of the 1920s all my life.  One of my favorite songs of all time is Singing in the Bathtub, a completely foolish and giddy song from 1928.  40 years of singing this song finally got to me and I looked the song up.  I found that it originally appeared in The Show of Shows.  Naturally, I had to order it if it was available, and it is.Now, I know that ancient movies and musicals are an acquired and somewhat eccentric taste.  I didn't expect my wife to care one way or the other about this film, but she actually put everything down and watched the entire thing.  Trust me, if a movie made over 83 years ago can have this kind of effect on someone who is not an aficionado of early show tunes and positively antediluvian approaches to filmmaking, it must be a good movie.  And boy, is it ever.Singing in the Bathtub is done so well, you'd wonder why you never heard it like this before.  Likewise Lady Luck, which was actually the A side of the original 78rpm disc.  (Few remember Lady Luck, however; the B side is the one we sing and whistle in the bathtub.)  Among the other highlights is John Barrymore giving a Shakespearean soliloquy (a full five minutes) and Sid Silvers doing a very funny Al Jolson skit.The dance numbers in the finale, particularly the tap dancing, will absolutely knock your socks off.This is most definitely worth seeking out.

reviewText: This film, which came out of Warners in late 1929, was their entry in the no-plot, all-star musical revues popular at the dawn of sound. Originally mostly in 2-color Technicolor, this surviving version is in black-and-white with the exception of a beautiful "Chinese Fantasy" sequence featuring Nick Lucas and Myrna Loy. Most of the performers featured here were Warner's silent performers, many of whom had backgrounds in theater and Vaudeville. Winnie Lightner shines here as a knock 'em in the aisles belter in the style of Betty Hutton, who may have been influenced by her. Irene Bordoni was a Broadway performer who gets a chance to sing here, and pretty well, too. The grand finale is huge, featuring 300 dancers and 15 individual acts. Pretty young things are attached to curtain pulls and chandeliers, and this must be seen to be believed. A pretty good representation of popular tastes back in the day, and a fascinating time capsule for film buffs.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This writer first saw THE SHOW OF SHOWS at a screening where the proprietors thought they were getting TEN FROM YOUR SHOW OF SHOWS. Make no mistake, this is not Sid Caesar!THE SHOW OF SHOWS is Warner Brothers' entry in the all-talking/all-singing/all-dancing revue sweepstakes of 1929-30. Warners didn't have the star names of M-G-M's HOLLYWOOD REVUE OF 1929; nor did they have the skill and slickness of PARAMOUNT ON PARADE; nor did they have the imagination and spirit of Universal's KING OF JAZZ. So Warners made do with what they did have: a few big-name stars, a master of ceremonies known for his biting wit, and a large roster of second-echelon players known more for their personalities than their acting abilities. The results are fascinating for fans of early-talkie cinema, diverting for old-movie fans in general, and boring for modern audiences who won't know who most of these people are.There are few solo spots because of the relative lack of star power -- many of the sketches present the players in groups. One is based on popular screen villains of the day (Noah Beery, Tully Marshall, etc.); another features starlets who happen to be sisters (Molly O'Day and Sally O'Neil, Alice and Marceline Day, etc.); another has six silent-era comedians as "The Floradora Boys" (a rare chance to hear the voices of Lupino Lane and Lloyd Hamilton); various leading men and women (Douglas Fairbanks, Jr., Jack Mulhall, Jacqueline Logan, et al.) shoehorned into a "gay-nineties" routine; and the grand finale is all-out vaudeville bedlam, with dancers, tumblers, and acrobats sharing the stage without distinction or even identification. Certain cast members appear only fleetingly, and some of the artists are not identified at all, notably champion prizefighter Georges Charpentier (who acquits himself quite nicely as a musical entertainer).This Warner revue satirizes M-G-M's revue in places, with ebullient Winnie Lightner clowning her way through "Singin' in the Bathtub," wrestler-actor Bull Montana good-naturedly singing "You Were Meant for Me," and some of the principals lampooning M-G-M's "mother" ballad. There is also a good sampling of popular music of the day: Ted Lewis and his jazz band, singer Nick Lucas and his guitar, and a Ziegfeldian "Chinese Fantasy" in Technicolor with Myrna Loy (and "introduced" by Rin Tin Tin!). Stage star Beatrice Lillie is quietly droll in a "poetry recital" bit. John Barrymore enacts a monologue from "Richard III," an excellent showcase for his thespic ability. Last but not least we have Frank Fay, master of ceremonies. Some viewers don't care for his I'm-above-it-all style but this writer likes him -- his self-assured delivery and genteel squelches (think of TV's Jack Cassidy) hold the various scenes together, and he actually does a torch song straight. Like him or not, Fay makes a good anchorman for this crazy-quilt show. And you will find some of this lengthy film crazy, or at least dubious: it actually opens with a black-comedy execution, with H. B. Warner of KING OF KINGS as the victim.Most of the two-hour film was originally in color. Warner Archive's DVD-R presents it almost entirely in black-and-white, comparable to its TV revivals of the 1950s and its cable-TV revival in the early 1990s. The "Chinese Fantasy" has been restored in its original, attractive two-color Technicolor. Reportedly additional color scenes have been restored since, but they are not found in this DVD.THE SHOW OF SHOWS is a museum piece and definitely a matter of taste. But if it's your kind of museum, you'll enjoy the exhibits.
summary: Antique musical-comedy pageant is a matter of taste; add 1 star if you like "dawn of sound" features
